section.title: HtmlUnit Overview
section.p: HtmlUnit is a java unit testing framework for testing web based applications. It is similar in concept to httpunit but is very different in implementation. Which one is better for you depends on how you like to write your tests. HttpUnit models the http protocol so you deal with request and response objects. HtmlUnit on the other hand, models the returned document so that you deal with pages and form and tables.
HtmlUnit was written by Mike Bowler of Gargoyle Software and has been released under an apache style license

section.title: Installation
section.p: Place the following jar files in your classpath. All of these can be found in the lib directory of the HtmlUnit installation.

dl.dd: HttpClient from Apache, the code that actually handles the http connections. Note that commons-httpclient is going through active development and does not have a stable release yet. We're using periodic "daily snapshots" which are actually quite solid.
NekoHTML is a tool to convert badly written html into an xml dom model
The Xerces xml parser from Apache.
Rhino, a javascript engine from the Mozilla project. This jar is optional - if it isn't found then javascript support will be disabled but the rest of HtmlUnit will continue to work.

p.note: If you want to use HTTPS (Secure HTTP) then you will have to have the JSSE in your classpath. JSSE is a standard part of Java starting with JDK1.4. If you are using an earlier version of Java, then you can download the JSSE from the Sun website.

section.title: JavaScript support
section.p: Starting with the 1.1 release, HtmlUnit is supporting javascript. The core javascript language is already fully supported by the Rhino javascript engine. The web browser specific host objects are being implemented now. We are focussing on those parts of javascript that are most commonly used first and will flesh out the remaining javascript support over time. If there is something specific that you need that we haven't got to yet then please open a feature request. We are prioritizing tasks according to demand so if you want a specific feature then make sure we know about it (opening a feature request is still the best way to do that).

note.title: Disabling JavaScript support
note.p: To disable JavaScript processing for one WebClient, call WebClient.setJavaScriptEnabled(false).
To disable JavaScript processing for all WebClients, remove js.jar from your classpath

section.p: Javascript code in script tags will get executed when the page loads. If you want to execute code after that, you can call HtmlPage.executeJavascriptIfPossible(String).
Refer to the changes document for details on what is being added.
